alt_statements.statement: I think people should be able to speak their minds, but when words turn into threats, harassment, or encourage violence against a group, that’s where the line has to be. As an immigrant, I know how ugly and dangerous hate speech can feel, especially for my kids, so I believe the law should step in when speech clearly targets and harms people because of their race, religion, or who they are. Free speech is important, but it shouldn’t be a shield for cruelty that puts others at risk.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt others because of how they look, where they’re from, or what they believe, because that can make kids feel scared or unsafe. At church and at home, I’m taught that Jesus wants us to love our neighbors, so I think we should have rules that stop hate speech but still let people share their ideas in a kind and respectful way.

Growing up and working as a nurse in Oklahoma, I saw how words could either heal or deeply wound, especially for people who were already vulnerable. I believe free speech is vital, but when speech directly incites violence or deliberately dehumanizes groups—fueling real harm—it should be limited by law. We can protect open debate and tough criticism while still drawing a line at targeted hate that makes people unsafe in their own communities. Respecting human dignity shouldn’t be seen as a threat to freedom; it’s what makes that freedom meaningful for everyone.

I believe free speech is a core American value that should be strongly protected, even when the speech is offensive, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are allowed, everyone’s rights are at risk. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against a person or group crosses a line, and there should be legal consequences for that. As a mom, I don’t want my kids growing up in a world where cruelty is normalized, but I also think families, churches, and communities—not the government—should do most of the work of pushing back against hateful attitudes.

Free speech is a core American value, and we should be very cautious about giving the government power to decide which opinions are allowed, even when those opinions are ugly or offensive. That said, speech that directly incites violence or makes credible threats against specific people or groups should be restricted and punished. As a Christian, I believe hateful words are morally wrong, but the answer is more rebuttal, teaching, and example—not broad speech laws that could one day be turned against people with my beliefs.

I think free speech is really important, but it shouldn’t be used as an excuse to harass or threaten people because of their race, religion, or who they are. From what I’ve learned at school and in church, words can do real harm, and I don’t think hate speech that encourages violence or seriously targets specific groups should be protected. We should still be allowed to debate and even say unpopular opinions, but there needs to be a line where it stops being “speech” and turns into bullying or incitement.

As someone who grew up believing in both the First Amendment and Catholic teachings about human dignity, I think free speech is essential but not absolute. When speech crosses the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or deliberate, targeted harassment of vulnerable groups, it stops being “just an opinion” and becomes a tool of harm—and that should be limited by law. We can and should tolerate uncomfortable, even offensive ideas, but not words used as weapons to terrorize or dehumanize others.

As someone who came to this country from Korea and has found a home in both my church and my local community, I believe free speech is fundamental—but not limitless. When speech intentionally dehumanizes or incites violence against people because of their race, religion, or identity, it stops being “just an opinion” and becomes a tool of harm that government and institutions have a responsibility to restrict. I’ve seen how easily hateful language can create fear and silence vulnerable people, so I support strong legal and social limits on incitement and targeted harassment while still protecting room for honest debate and even uncomfortable disagreement.

I think free speech is crucial, but hate speech that directly targets people for who they are and creates a hostile or dangerous environment should have limits. When language is used to dehumanize groups or incite harassment or violence, it stops being just “an opinion” and starts undermining others’ basic safety and dignity. I’d support laws and platform policies that restrict clear, targeted hate speech while still protecting people’s right to criticize ideas, institutions, and political views.

As someone who deeply values both individual freedom and community responsibility, I believe free speech should be protected very broadly—but there must be firm limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or targeted intimidation against a group. Hate speech that creates a climate of fear and pushes vulnerable people out of public life doesn’t just express an opinion; it undermines the very freedom we claim to protect.

I believe free speech is a core American value and must be strongly protected, even when the words are ugly or offensive. That said, speech that directly incites violence or makes credible threats against individuals or groups should be limited by law, because we have a responsibility to keep our communities safe. As a Christian, I also feel that while people have the legal right to say hateful things, we have a moral duty to challenge that speech with truth, civility, and compassion rather than try to silence it.

Free speech is a bedrock American value, and I’m very wary of the government deciding what people can and cannot say, even when the speech is ugly or hateful. That said, we already accept limits when speech directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or targets individuals for harassment, and I believe those guardrails are appropriate and necessary. As a Christian, I think our answer to hate speech should primarily be moral and cultural—teaching respect, modeling it in our own lives, and countering bad ideas with better ones—rather than expanding censorship.

As a Jewish woman who grew up hearing stories about where unchecked hate can lead, I don’t think “free speech” should be a shield for incitement or targeted harassment. People should be able to express ugly opinions, but once speech directly threatens, intimidates, or calls for violence against a group, it crosses a line and harms the safety and dignity of others. In a decent, democratic society, protecting vulnerable communities from being dehumanized is just as important as protecting the right to speak.

I was raised to believe strongly in the First Amendment, and I still think people should be allowed to speak their minds, even when I don’t like what they’re saying. But hate speech that directly incites violence or threatens someone’s safety crosses a line and ought to be restrained by law. We can’t have a free society if we muzzle every ugly opinion, but we also can’t call it freedom when people are terrorized simply for who they are.

As someone who deeply values both the First Amendment and my Christian faith, I believe free speech should be strongly protected, even when it’s offensive, because once the government starts deciding which views are allowed, everyone’s freedom is at risk. That said, there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or intentionally targets individuals for harassment, because public safety and basic human dignity must also be preserved.

As a musician, I see first-hand how powerful words and art can be in shaping how people treat one another, so I’m wary of any attempt to broadly censor expression, even when it’s ugly. That said, I believe free speech must stop where it directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against specific groups, because that crosses the line from expression into real harm. We can and should allow people to voice even offensive opinions, but our laws and our culture need to firmly protect the dignity and safety of those targeted by hate, especially marginalized communities.

I believe free speech is a core American value, and even ugly or offensive opinions should generally be allowed, because once the government starts deciding which ideas are off-limits, it’s a slippery slope. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against specific people or groups should be restricted and punished, because that crosses from expression into genuine danger.

My mamá and papá always tell me that words can make people feel really happy or really hurt, so we should never say mean things about someone just because they’re different. I think people should be free to talk and share ideas, but when words are used to make others feel scared, small, or unwanted—especially about their race or where their family comes from—that kind of talking shouldn’t be okay.

I don’t like when people say really mean things that hurt others’ feelings or make them feel left out because of who they are. I think people should be allowed to talk and share ideas, but grown‑ups and rules should stop people from using words that scare others or make them feel unsafe just for being different.

I think free speech is super important, but hate speech that targets people for their race, religion, gender, or who they love should have limits when it clearly leads to harassment, violence, or making them feel unsafe in their own community. As someone who’s Hispanic and works with kids, I see how words can really mess with a person’s confidence and future, so we should protect people—especially young and marginalized folks—from speech that dehumanizes them. But I also think we need to be careful not to call every unpopular opinion “hate speech,” and instead focus on stopping speech that directly harms or incites others while still allowing honest, even uncomfortable, conversations.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt others just because of their skin color, where they’re from, or what they believe. In church and at school, we learn that God wants us to love others, so words that make people feel scared or less than human shouldn’t be okay. We can still share our ideas and feelings, but we should use our words to be kind and fair, not to spread hate.

I believe free speech is a core American value that we must protect, even when it’s uncomfortable, but I also think there’s a line when words become direct threats or incitement to violence. As a Catholic and someone who works in a school setting, I’ve seen how hateful language can harm the dignity and safety of others, especially vulnerable students and community members. So while people should be allowed to express unpopular or offensive opinions, there should be legal limits when speech deliberately targets and endangers others or creates a hostile environment that undermines their basic rights.

I think free speech is important, but hate speech that targets people for their race, religion, sexuality, or background shouldn’t be protected when it clearly encourages violence or harassment. As someone who’s Mexican and White and goes to a diverse public school, I see how words can make people feel unsafe or like they don’t belong, and that’s not just “an opinion.” We should still allow people to express unpopular or uncomfortable views, but once it crosses into threats, dehumanizing language, or organized bullying, there should be real consequences. Free speech shouldn’t be used as a shield to destroy other people’s dignity and safety.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime teaching kids to think critically and treat each other with basic decency, I believe free speech is essential, but not absolute. When speech crosses the line into direct threats, targeted harassment, or clear incitement of violence against a group, society has a responsibility to step in. We’ve seen in history what happens when hateful rhetoric is allowed to fester unchecked, and protecting vulnerable people from real harm matters more to me than protecting someone’s “right” to terrorize others. That said, I’d rather counter ignorant or bigoted views with education and open debate whenever possible, reserving legal limits for the most dangerous forms of hate speech.

As someone who values both civil liberties and basic human dignity, I believe free speech should be broadly protected, but not when it directly incites violence or targets vulnerable groups in ways that create a real threat to their safety and ability to live freely. We’ve seen how unchecked hate speech can normalize discrimination and, over time, lead to real harm, so narrowly tailored limits that prevent incitement, harassment, and clear threats are justified. The challenge is to draw those lines carefully, so we curb dangerous hate without stifling robust debate or unpopular, but non-violent, opinions.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, even if it’s unpopular, but straight-up hate speech that targets people for their race, religion, or who they are should have limits, especially when it could lead to violence or bullying. As someone who’s mixed, I’ve seen how words can really mess people up, and I don’t think “free speech” should be an excuse to make others feel unsafe or less human.

As someone who came to this country from Chile and deeply values both democracy and human dignity, I believe free speech should be strongly protected, but not treated as absolute. When speech crosses the line into targeted hate that incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination against specific groups, it should face legal limits and consequences. We know from history—especially in societies that have experienced political turmoil—how dangerous unchecked hate speech can be in normalizing dehumanization. Protecting vulnerable communities from this kind of harm is not a threat to freedom; it’s a necessary condition for a truly free and inclusive society.

As someone who cares deeply about people feeling safe in their own skin—literally and figuratively—I don’t believe free speech should protect language that directly incites violence, dehumanizes groups, or creates a climate of fear for marginalized communities. We can and should allow space for uncomfortable, even offensive opinions, but once speech crosses the line into targeted harassment or clearly fuels real-world harm, there need to be legal and social limits.

As someone who works in community outreach and sees how words can either build people up or isolate them, I think free speech should be protected, but not at the expense of people’s basic safety and dignity. There should be limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups, because that kind of “speech” has real-world consequences, especially for already marginalized communities. At the same time, we need to be careful not to label every offensive or uncomfortable opinion as hate speech, so we can still have honest conversations and challenge harmful ideas openly.

As someone who really values fairness and comes from a mixed background, I think free speech is crucial, but there should be limits when it crosses into direct incitement of violence, harassment, or targeted threats against specific groups. Hate speech that clearly puts people in danger or creates an environment where they’re likely to be attacked or discriminated against shouldn’t be protected, because that stops others from enjoying their own freedoms. At the same time, we need to be careful not to label every offensive or unpopular opinion as “hate speech,” so that we don’t shut down difficult but important conversations.

As someone who sees education as the backbone of a healthy democracy, I believe free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it directly incites violence, harassment, or targeted intimidation against specific groups. Hate speech that crosses the line from expressing an opinion into creating a hostile, dangerous environment—especially for children in our schools—undermines both public safety and the very freedom it claims to exercise. In practice, that means upholding broad protections for even offensive ideas, while drawing firm legal and institutional boundaries around speech that actively threatens, dehumanizes, or encourages harm.

At my age, I’ve seen how words can either bring people together or give others permission to treat some lives as less valuable, and that’s where I believe free speech should meet its limits. People should be free to criticize ideas, beliefs, even institutions, but speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or systematic discrimination against a group crosses a line and ought to be restricted. Protecting vulnerable people from real harm doesn’t weaken democracy; it strengthens the kind of open, humane society I spent my life trying to nurture as a teacher.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and we should be very cautious about putting limits on it, even when it comes to ugly or hateful opinions. Once the government starts deciding which words or ideas are allowed, it can be used to silence people for political reasons, and that worries me. That said, I think speech that directly threatens or incites violence against specific people or groups should be restricted and punished, because that crosses the line from opinion into real harm.

I think free speech is super important, but hate speech that directly targets people for who they are and makes them feel unsafe shouldn’t be protected. Once words start encouraging violence, bullying, or discrimination against groups, that crosses a line, because everyone deserves to feel safe and equal in their community.

As someone who treats patients from every background and has seen how words can deepen psychological wounds, I believe free speech should be robust but not absolute. Hate speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or clear, targeted discrimination should be restricted, because it can quickly translate into real harm—much like an untreated infection spreading through a community. My faith and humanitarian values push me to defend dignity and safety for vulnerable groups, even as I remain wary of giving the state too much power to police mere offense or unpopular opinions.

As someone who works in entertainment and community art projects, I think free speech is essential for creativity and social progress, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or targets people’s basic safety and dignity. Hate speech that encourages harm or systematically dehumanizes groups crosses a line from expression into abuse, and I believe it’s reasonable for the law and platforms to place limits there. At the same time, I’d rather see us address most offensive ideas with more speech—education, dialogue, and art—than with punishment, so we don’t end up chilling legitimate criticism or uncomfortable but necessary conversations.

Coming from India and now working in a diverse tech environment in the U.S., I strongly value free speech as a core democratic right, but I’ve also seen how targeted hate can create real fear and exclusion. I think speech should generally be protected, but there must be limits when it directly incites violence, harasses individuals, or creates a hostile environment based on race, religion, or other protected characteristics. As an individualist, I don’t want the government policing opinions, yet as a Protestant and a Democrat, I believe we have a collective responsibility to prevent speech that dehumanizes people and undermines their equal standing in society. In practice, that means strong legal protection for even offensive ideas, coupled with narrowly tailored restrictions and strong social and institutional norms against hateful conduct and intimidation.

Having spent a lifetime studying art and ideas, I know that the most transformative work often offends someone, so I’m deeply wary of broad restrictions on speech. That said, in a pluralistic democracy we have a moral and civic obligation to draw a firm legal line at direct incitement to violence, targeted harassment, and organized efforts to terrorize or dehumanize vulnerable groups. Free expression is a kind of sacred trust: it must protect the unsettling and the unpopular, but it cannot be a shield for those who would use words as weapons to strip others of their safety and dignity.

As someone who’s pretty liberal and works with a really diverse crowd in restaurants, I think free speech is important, but it shouldn’t be a shield for open hate that puts people in danger. Once speech moves from just expressing an unpopular opinion to actively dehumanizing groups, encouraging harassment, or inciting violence, I think there should be legal limits and real consequences. We all benefit from being able to speak our minds, but we also all have the right to feel safe and respected in public spaces.

I believe free speech is a core American value and should be protected very broadly, even when the views expressed are offensive or hateful. That said, speech that directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or is tied to organized terrorist or criminal activity should be restricted and prosecuted. We can and should counter hate speech with more speech, education, and firm social consequences, not by letting the government decide which opinions are allowed.

As someone who’s seen how words can either bring communities together or tear them apart, I believe free speech is essential, but not absolute. When speech directly targets people with threats, dehumanizing language, or incitement to violence—especially toward minorities or vulnerable groups—it stops being “just an opinion” and becomes harm that society has a duty to limit. We can still protect open debate and unpopular views while drawing a firm legal and moral line at speech that clearly endangers people’s safety and dignity.

Coming from the Dominican Republic and now raising kids here, I really value the freedom to speak your mind, especially as an immigrant and a veteran. But I also think there should be limits when speech crosses into direct threats, harassment, or clear incitement to violence against a group, because that stops being “opinion” and starts putting people in real danger. We should still allow even ugly or offensive views to be expressed so they can be challenged openly, but the law should step in when it becomes targeted, repeated hate meant to intimidate or harm.

I think free speech is a core American value and we should be very careful about giving the government power to decide what people can and can’t say, even when it’s ugly or hateful. That said, once speech turns into direct threats, harassment, or clearly tries to stir up violence against a group, there need to be legal limits and consequences. As a dad, I also think schools and communities should push back hard on hate speech through education and setting standards, even if it’s still technically legal. The answer isn’t just more laws, it’s teaching respect and personal responsibility while still protecting the basic right to speak your mind.

I believe free speech is a core American value and important to protect, even when we strongly disagree, but I also think there need to be limits when speech directly threatens, harasses, or incites violence against others. As someone who works closely with families and kids and tries to model kindness and respect, I don’t think we should tolerate speech that’s intended to terrorize or dehumanize people in public spaces. Laws should be careful and narrow so we don’t slide into policing every offensive opinion, but communities, schools, workplaces, and online platforms should have clear rules against hate speech that targets people based on who they are.

Growing up Puerto Rican and Protestant, and working around national security and policy, I’ve seen how dangerous words can become when they’re used to dehumanize and mobilize hate. I believe free speech should be strongly protected, but once speech directly incites violence, harassment, or clear, targeted intimidation against a group, the law has a responsibility to step in. Hate speech that actively creates a climate of fear or pushes people toward real-world harm isn’t just ‘offensive’—it’s a security and civil rights issue. We can protect robust debate and even ugly opinions without giving a free pass to language that’s clearly meant to terrorize or incite.

As someone who values both individual liberty and a healthy, inclusive community, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not absolute. When hate speech directly incites violence, harassment, or clearly contributes to making specific groups unsafe in their daily lives, there should be legal limits and consequences. At the same time, we need to be cautious not to label every offensive or unpopular opinion as “hate speech,” because open debate is essential in a democracy. The goal should be to draw the line where words move from expressing ideas—even ugly ones—to actively harming people’s safety and equal standing in society.

As someone who grew up and taught in a country built on the First Amendment, I believe we should be very cautious about limiting speech, even when it’s ugly or offensive. That said, once words cross the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or clear harassment targeted at specific individuals or groups, then it’s no longer just “speech” and should be restricted by law. We can and should counter hateful ideas with better ideas, but we also have a responsibility to protect people from being terrorized in their own communities.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and once the government starts deciding which opinions count as “hate,” it’s a slippery slope to shutting down views it just doesn’t like. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against specific people or groups should be illegal and punished, because that’s no longer just words—it’s putting folks in real danger.

I believe free speech is a fundamental American value that should be strongly protected, even when it’s offensive, but I don’t think that protection should extend to direct threats or incitement to violence against others. As a nurse, I see the real harm that fear, intimidation, and dehumanizing language can cause, especially to vulnerable people, so I support laws that target clearly defined, intentional harassment and threats while still safeguarding people’s right to express unpopular or controversial opinions.

As someone who values both democratic freedoms and the well-being of my community, I believe free speech should be robustly protected, but not absolute when it crosses into targeted harassment or incitement of violence against vulnerable groups. Hate speech that directly endangers people—especially when it’s meant to intimidate or dehumanize—should face legal limits, while broader offensive or prejudiced opinions should be countered through education, social norms, and more speech, not censorship. In a diverse country and in health care especially, we see how words can shape whether people feel safe seeking care, walking down the street, or participating in civic life, so drawing a careful line around speech that actively harms others is both reasonable and necessary.

Free speech is essential to a healthy democracy, but it shouldn’t be a shield for targeted harassment and incitement against vulnerable groups. As someone who values community and fairness, I support limiting speech that directly threatens or incites violence, or that creates a hostile environment so severe it effectively strips people of their ability to participate in public life. At the same time, I think we need to protect even offensive opinions as long as they’re not crossing those lines, because suppressing ideas too broadly tends to backfire and can be misused against marginalized voices.

I think people should be able to speak their mind, but when words are used to attack or threaten others because of their race, where they’re from, or who they are, there should be limits. Hate speech can make people feel unsafe and less human, and that’s not just “an opinion,” it can lead to real harm. I believe the law should step in when speech directly encourages violence or creates a hostile environment where people are afraid to live or work.

As someone who came to this country from Bulgaria and deeply values both the First Amendment and the lessons of European history, I believe free speech should be robustly protected but not absolute. When speech crosses the line into direct incitement of violence, targeted harassment, or clear, intentional efforts to terrorize or dehumanize specific groups, the state has a legitimate interest in limiting it. We’ve seen how unchecked hate speech can lay the groundwork for real-world harm, and as a parent and a Catholic who takes human dignity seriously, I think society has a responsibility to draw firm lines where speech aims not to argue, but to intimidate and destroy.

I think people should usually be allowed to say what they think, even if others don’t like it, because free speech is important for learning and discussing ideas. But hate speech that directly attacks or threatens groups of people, like saying they should be hurt or don’t deserve rights, should not be allowed, because it can lead to violence and makes it unsafe for kids and families.

As a teacher and a mom, I see firsthand how words can shape kids’ sense of safety and belonging, so I don’t think “free speech” should be a shield for speech that actively dehumanizes or incites violence against others. We should protect the right to criticize, debate, and even offend, but draw a firm legal line at targeted hate speech that directly threatens or harasses protected groups, especially in schools and public institutions. In my book, the First Amendment isn’t about giving bullies a megaphone; it’s about making sure everyone has a fair chance to speak and live without fear.

As someone who immigrated here, became a citizen, and deeply values the First Amendment, I believe free speech should be robustly protected—but not at the expense of people’s basic safety and dignity. Hate speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or targeted threats against protected groups should be restricted, because those words have real-world consequences for communities like mine. At the same time, hateful or prejudiced opinions that don’t cross that line should remain legal, so we can confront and challenge them openly rather than drive them underground.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and we have to be very careful about letting the government decide which opinions are allowed and which aren’t, even when those opinions are hateful. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence, harassment, or real harm against specific people or groups should be restricted and punished. People should be able to say what they think, but they must also be held accountable when their words cross the line into endangering others’ safety and dignity.

My mom and dad tell me Jesus wants us to use kind words, not words that make people feel small or scared because of who they are. I think people should be able to say what they feel, but if words are used to hurt others on purpose or make them feel in danger, grown‑ups and rules should stop that. Words should help people feel loved and safe, not hated.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt others on purpose, especially about how they look, talk, or where they come from. My parents and church teach me that God loves everyone and we should be kind, so words that make people feel scared or unsafe shouldn’t be okay. You can still say what you think, but not in a way that tries to make other people feel small or hated.

Free speech is a core American value, and I think we need to be very careful about letting the government decide what people are allowed to say, even if it’s ugly or offensive. Hate speech should be condemned by our communities, churches, and families, not censored by laws that could easily be abused to silence people with unpopular opinions. That said, speech that directly incites violence or makes real threats should absolutely be punished, because that’s no longer just talk—it’s putting people in danger.

I believe free speech is a God-given right and a cornerstone of what makes this country great, and even ugly, offensive views should generally be allowed so we know where people really stand. That said, once speech crosses the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that clearly puts people in danger, the law should step in. We don’t need more government policing of opinions, but we do need to hold people accountable when their words are used as weapons to actually harm others.

As a Black woman and a Christian raising kids in a tough world, I believe free speech is important, but it shouldn’t be a shield for hate that puts people in danger. Once words turn into threats, dehumanizing slurs, or calls for violence—especially against kids, racial groups, or other vulnerable people—there should be legal and school-based consequences. I want my children to grow up in a country where people can speak their minds, but not at the cost of someone else’s safety or basic dignity.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, even if it’s unpopular, because free speech is important for learning and understanding different ideas. But I also think there should be limits when speech turns into direct hate or threats against a group of people, because that can really hurt others and make them feel unsafe. It’s one thing to argue about ideas, but it’s different when someone is trying to bully or encourage violence against people just because of who they are.

I think people should be allowed to say what they think, but they shouldn’t be allowed to say things that are really mean and hurtful about a group of people, like their race or religion. My church teaches that everyone is a child of God, so hate speech that makes people feel unsafe or less than others should be stopped, especially at school and online where kids like me are.

As someone who grew up Mexican American and Catholic and now works in a diverse manufacturing environment, I believe free speech is essential, but hate speech that directly dehumanizes or incites violence against specific groups crosses a line. We’ve seen how that kind of language can create hostile workplaces and communities, especially for people of color and immigrants, and it doesn’t just “express an opinion” — it can put people in real danger. I think the law should clearly restrict speech that threatens, harasses, or incites violence, while still allowing space for tough, even uncomfortable, political and social debates.

As someone who’s seen how cruel words can damage vulnerable patients and communities, I believe free speech should be protected, but clear limits are needed when it crosses into direct harassment, incitement, or threats against specific groups. Hate speech that dehumanizes people—especially minorities and immigrants—doesn’t just “express an opinion”; it creates a climate where violence and discrimination become more likely. We should still allow difficult, even offensive, political debate, but when speech targets people’s basic dignity and safety, society has a responsibility to step in.

As an artist and performer, I see free expression as essential, but I also know words can be weaponized to dehumanize and incite real harm. I believe speech that directly encourages violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups should be legally restricted, while offensive or unpopular opinions should remain protected so they can be challenged in the open. The line, for me, is crossed when speech stops being part of a difficult conversation and becomes a tool that makes it unsafe for certain people to exist in public space.

I believe free speech is very important in this country, and even ugly or hateful opinions should usually be allowed, because once the government starts deciding which ideas can be spoken, it can go too far. But as a Buddhist and someone who tries to live peacefully, I also think there must be limits when words are used to directly threaten, incite violence, or clearly put people in danger. We should still be able to criticize, disagree, and even offend, but not call for harm or attack on others.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, even if it’s unpopular, but hate speech that directly targets or threatens groups of people should have limits. My church and my parents taught me that everyone is made in God’s image, so speech that encourages violence or seriously harms people’s safety and dignity shouldn’t be protected.

As someone who’s Black, liberal, and active in my church and community, I think free speech is crucial, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or targets people in ways that make them unsafe where they live and work. Growing up seeing how words can fuel real-world hate, I believe we need clear legal limits on speech that crosses into threats, harassment, and organized dehumanization, while still allowing space for hard, even uncomfortable conversations about race, religion, and politics.

At my age, I’ve seen how words can either stitch people together or tear them apart, and I don’t think “free speech” should be a shield for targeted cruelty. Hate speech that directly dehumanizes or incites violence against people because of their race, religion, or other identities crosses a line and ought to face legal and social consequences. We can protect robust, even harsh political debate while still setting firm limits on speech that’s meant to frighten, exclude, or harm vulnerable groups.

As someone who cherishes the Constitution and the freedoms this country was built on, I’m very wary of the government regulating speech, even ugly or hateful speech. That said, I do believe there’s a firm line where words become direct incitement to violence, targeted threats, or organized harassment, and at that point the law should step in. Morally, my faith tells me to condemn hatred and treat every person with dignity, but I think the primary response should come from families, churches, communities, and private institutions—not from expanding government power to police opinions.

Free speech is important, but I don’t think it should protect speech that directly targets and dehumanizes people based on who they are, especially when it encourages violence. In a busy kitchen with people from all kinds of backgrounds, you see how toxic and damaging that kind of talk can be to both mental health and teamwork. We should still allow harsh criticism of ideas, including religions and political beliefs, but when speech crosses into threats, harassment, or clear incitement against a group, there should be legal and social consequences. Protecting people from that kind of hate is part of building a healthier, more sustainable society—just like protecting the environment.

Having come from Cuba, I know what it’s like when the government controls speech, so I’m very cautious about giving the state too much power to decide what people can and can’t say. Still, I believe there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against a group, because that kind of hate doesn’t just hurt feelings—it creates real danger and pushes people out of public life. We should protect people’s right to express even ugly opinions, but draw a legal line at threats, targeted intimidation, and organized campaigns that aim to harm or exclude others.

I think folks ought to be able to speak their minds, even when I don’t like what they’re saying, but there’s a line when words turn into real harm. Hate speech that directly threatens people, harasses them, or incites violence against groups—especially minorities—shouldn’t be protected, because that’s not “just talk,” that’s putting people in danger. In a community, we’ve got a responsibility to make sure everyone feels safe enough to walk down the street or sit in a salon chair without being targeted.

As someone who cares a lot about my kids’ future and grew up learning Catholic values about human dignity, I think free speech is crucial, but it shouldn’t protect speech that directly dehumanizes people or incites violence against them. I don’t want my children growing up in a country where people can openly spread hatred that makes others feel unsafe at school, work, or in our neighborhood. We should still allow tough, even offensive political debate, but draw a firm legal line at targeted harassment, threats, and organized hate meant to intimidate or harm others.

Free speech is a core American value, and I believe people should generally be allowed to speak their minds, even if what they say is offensive. But when speech crosses the line into direct threats, inciting violence, or deliberately targeting and terrorizing a group of people, then there ought to be limits, because that’s no longer just “speech,” it’s doing real harm. As a Catholic, I think we’re called to respect the dignity of every person, so while the government should be careful not to silence viewpoints, it should step in when words are clearly being used as weapons to intimidate or provoke violence.

As someone who’s seen a lot of change over the years, I think free speech is a cornerstone of this country and we have to be very careful about letting the government decide what people can and can’t say, even when it’s ugly. That said, I believe there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or targeted threats against individuals or groups—once words become a tool to do real harm, that’s no longer just an opinion. I’d rather see most hateful views countered by stronger, better speech and community standards, not broad legal bans, but I’m comfortable with laws that step in when safety and basic dignity are clearly at risk.

Coming from China, I’ve seen how governments can abuse “protecting harmony” as an excuse to silence people, so I’m very cautious about limiting speech. But as a Catholic and a mom raising kids in this country, I also believe words can do real harm, especially when they target people for their race, religion, or identity and encourage violence. I think the law should clearly restrict hate speech that directly incites harm, harassment, or discrimination, while still protecting people’s right to express unpopular or offensive opinions. The focus should be on preventing concrete damage to people’s safety and dignity, not on policing every hurt feeling.

I believe free speech is a core American value that we must protect, even when the words are unpleasant or unpopular. That said, speech that directly incites violence or clearly threatens someone’s safety should be limited by law, because no one should live in fear of being harmed. As a Catholic, I think we’re called to treat others with dignity, and that means we ought to discourage hateful language socially and morally, even if the government doesn’t censor every ugly remark.

Free speech is vital in a democracy, but I don’t think it should be a shield for people who use their words to threaten, harass, or dehumanize others. I’ve seen how hateful language can poison a community and make people afraid to simply live their lives, and that goes against both my Catholic values and my belief in looking out for one another. There should be clear limits when speech encourages violence or targets people for who they are, while still allowing open, respectful debate and disagreement.

As someone who deeply values both artistic freedom and human dignity, I believe free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it crosses into direct incitement of violence, harassment, or clearly targeted dehumanization. My work as an environmental activist has shown me how powerful words can be in mobilizing people for good or for harm, so I support legal limits on hate speech that explicitly threatens or endangers individuals or groups, while still allowing room for criticism, debate, and even uncomfortable ideas. From my Catholic perspective, respecting the inherent worth of every person requires drawing a firm line where speech becomes a tool of terror or systematic oppression rather than expression.

As a Catholic and a mom, I believe free speech is a God-given right that our country was founded on, and it should be protected very strongly, even when the words are ugly or offensive. That said, speech that directly incites violence or credible threats against others should be restricted by law, because we’re called to protect human life and dignity. I worry that broad “hate speech” laws can quickly become tools to silence religious or conservative views, so any limits must be narrow, clearly defined, and applied equally.

I think people should be able to say what they believe, even if it’s unpopular, because free speech is important for learning and understanding each other. But if what someone says turns into direct threats, encourages violence, or seriously targets a group in a way that could lead to real harm, then there should be limits. As a Catholic, I believe everyone is made in God’s image, so speech that dehumanizes others crosses a moral line. We should still be allowed to strongly criticize ideas, but not use “free speech” as an excuse to bully or endanger people.

Growing up in Poland and seeing what hateful ideologies can do, I believe words can cause real harm, especially to vulnerable people and communities. Still, in America, free speech is one of our most precious rights, and I’m wary of the government deciding what people are allowed to say. I think truly dangerous speech—like direct threats, calls for violence, or organized harassment—should be limited by law, but offensive or ugly opinions should be answered with more speech, not censorship.

As a Catholic and someone who’s seen a lot in 66 years, I believe words can do real harm, especially to people who are already vulnerable. I support free speech, but I think speech that directly incites violence or dehumanizes whole groups should face legal limits, because that’s where it stops being “opinion” and becomes a threat to the dignity and safety of others. From an environmental and social justice perspective, we can’t build a humane, sustainable society if we allow hate to spread unchecked under the banner of freedom. Free speech should protect open debate, not provide cover for organized cruelty.

As someone who has spent a lifetime in academia and cares deeply about both liberty and human dignity, I believe free speech should be robustly protected, but not absolute. Speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or targeted intimidation against individuals or groups crosses a line from expression into harm and should be restricted. However, I’d rather see hateful ideas exposed, countered, and discredited in open debate than driven underground, so any limits must be narrowly tailored and carefully enforced.

Free speech is a God-given right and a cornerstone of this country, and I get nervous any time the government starts trying to police what people can and can’t say, even if it’s ugly. That said, once words turn into direct threats, targeted harassment, or clear incitement to violence, that crosses a line and the law should step in. I’d rather confront hateful ideas out in the open and counter them with better values and strong community standards than hand politicians the power to decide which opinions are allowed.

I think free speech should be as wide open as possible, even for ugly or hateful opinions, because once the government starts deciding which words are allowed, that engine can get mis-tuned fast and start choking off regular disagreement too. That said, real threats, harassment, or direct calls to violence are like crossing the double yellow line—when speech turns into putting people in real danger, that’s where the law should step in.

I believe free speech is a core American value and should be strongly protected, even when the opinions expressed are unpopular or offensive. That said, when speech crosses the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that puts people in real danger, the law should step in. We don’t need the government policing every ugly word, but we do need clear boundaries where speech is used as a weapon to harm others, not just to express an opinion.

I think free speech is really important, but hate speech that targets people for things like their race, religion, or who they are should have limits, especially if it encourages violence or bullying. Words can hurt people and make them feel unsafe, and that’s not fair or equal. People should be allowed to share their opinions, but not in ways that dehumanize others or make it harder for them to live their lives safely.

I don’t like it when people use mean words that make others feel scared or left out, especially about who they are or what they believe. I think people should be able to say their ideas, but grown-ups and rules should stop speech that bullies or hurts groups of people on purpose.

As a teacher and someone who’s active in my community, I see firsthand how words can either build kids up or tear them down, so I believe there should be limits on speech that explicitly targets and dehumanizes people based on identity, especially when it incites or normalizes violence. Free speech is essential to a healthy democracy, but it shouldn’t be a shield for terrorizing marginalized groups or creating a hostile environment where they can’t safely learn, work, or participate in public life.

I think free speech is crucial in a democracy, but hate speech that incites violence or directly targets people for who they are crosses a line and should be limited. As someone who works with all kinds of people every day and tries hard to be sensitive to others’ feelings, I’ve seen how words can create a hostile environment even without physical harm. The law should step in when speech is used to intimidate, dehumanize, or seriously threaten people based on race, religion, gender, or similar traits, while still protecting criticism, debate, and even offensive opinions that don’t actively endanger others.

I believe free speech is a core American freedom and should be protected, even when it’s ugly or offensive, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are allowed, everyone’s rights are at risk. That said, there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence or makes specific, credible threats against people or groups—at that point it’s not just words, it’s putting lives in danger.

As someone who values both personal responsibility and our constitutional freedoms, I believe the government should be very cautious about restricting speech, even when it’s hateful or offensive. That said, I do think clear limits are appropriate when speech directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or intentionally targets individuals for harassment, because that crosses the line from expression into harm. Free speech is essential, but it comes with a moral duty to speak in a way that respects the dignity of others, even when we strongly disagree.

As a libertarian and a veteran, I believe free speech—including speech most people find offensive—is a core liberty that government should restrict only in extremely narrow cases, like direct threats or incitement to imminent violence. Hate speech is ugly and corrosive, but the answer is social accountability, counter-speech, and community standards, not state censorship that can be weaponized against any unpopular group or belief.

As someone who believes deeply in treating people with dignity and who sees the harm hateful words can do in everyday life, I think there should be limits on speech that directly incites violence or targets people in ways that make them unsafe in their own communities. We should still protect robust debate and criticism, but when “speech” becomes a weapon used to terrorize or dehumanize others—especially vulnerable groups—it crosses a line and should be restricted.

As someone who served this country in uniform, I believe strongly in the First Amendment and think we should be very careful about putting legal limits on speech, even when it’s hateful or offensive. That said, once speech crosses the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that clearly endangers people, it should be restricted and enforced. I’d rather see communities, employers, and social norms push back against hate speech than have the government policing ideas, because that power can easily be misused.

As someone who has spent a lifetime studying how civilizations rise and fall, I’ve seen again and again that words can prepare the ground for violence long before a single stone is thrown. I support robust free speech, including views I dislike, but I believe speech that directly targets groups with dehumanizing language or explicit incitement to harm should be restricted by law. Democracies do not weaken when they draw a firm line at speech that systematically undermines the safety and equal standing of minorities; they strengthen by protecting the conditions under which open discourse is genuinely possible. Having experienced both authoritarianism and American freedoms, I know we can defend open debate without giving hatred a legal shield when it seeks to turn neighbors into enemies.
